stories.text:
Back in the 90s, we used to have CRT monitors, and they almost always had physical/mechanical dials for brightness/contrast settings. I'm prone to headaches looking at bright screens, so I often need to have different brightness/contrast settings in the day time vs night time. They were really convenient.

Nowadays - laptops are OK in this case because there's usually buttons on the keyboard to quickly adjust brightness.

For desktop PCs, every LCD/LED monitor I've owned has brightness/contrast settings buried in software menus. It makes it very hard to adjust brightness/contrast on a regular basis. I rely on night light settings (bluelight filters) in software to help myself feel better without having to fiddle with the monitor's menu (which is always really cumbersome to use).

Are there LCE/LED monitors with physical dials, or at a minimum dedicated physical buttons for brightness/contrast (and not buried within menus with buttons labeled "1", "2", etc.)?
stories.title: Ask HN: Monitor with physical dials for brightness/contrast?

Like screen time, which is useless since it tries to "block" the site and dose not allow me then to write to my friends. (and u need 2 clicks to bypass this which is now part of my habit, I have not removed it because this will take more energy than just these 2 clicks)

I tried to use DNS blocks, but the it has the same problem.

So my idea is that not the content or algorithms are the problem, it is the speed and the occurring instand gratification.

I would like to ask what would be the best way to slow down, for example instagram reddit HN.

My idea would be a VPN, since it needs to work on my iPhone to.

I cloud set up firewall rules that speeds down certain IPs to 50kb/s. BUT I need the IPs from the entire networks which are many and my change. And it need to just work automatically, without future intervention.

My idea was to build something like a DNS interceptor which inserts the IPs and inserts them into the firewall. But this seams to be a lot of work?

So tell me HN, what do you think would be the best approach?
